did.abstract: Andolan (Organizing South Asian Workers) is a non-governmental, membership based group in New York City that organizes and advocates on behalf of South Asian immigrant workers, with particular focus on Bangladeshi, Pakistani, Indian, Nepalese, and Sri Lankan workers in the retail, food service, and domestic work industries, many of whom are women. Founded in 1998 by low-wage South Asians, Andolan's goal is to support and empower working-class communities to realize their rights and overcome obstacles such as language barriers, discrimination, immigration status, and gaps in social services for legal assistance and other types of support. The Andolan (Organizing South Asian Workers) Records (dated 1998-2007) consists of materials created and collected by Andolan documenting the organization's activism and advocacy on behalf of South Asian workers in New York City in the domestic work, restaurant, and retail industries. Materials in this collection include photographs, administrative records, client court case files, financial records, grant applications, and ephemera from demonstrations and other events. The majority of the collection consists of court files documenting Andolan's role in legal services on behalf of low-wage South Asian workers related to wage compensation, political asylum, and domestic violence.
did.langmaterial: Majority of materials are in English, with some newspapers and ephemera in Hindi and Bengali. Some items are bi-lingual.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Andolan (Organizing South Asian Workers) Records (dated 1998-2007) consists of materials created and collected by Andolan documenting the organization's activism and advocacy on behalf of South Asian workers in New York City in the domestic work, restaurant, and retail industries. Materials in this collection include photographs, administrative records, client court case files, financial records, grant applications, and ephemera from demonstrations and other events. The majority of the collection consists of court files documenting Andolan's role in legal services on behalf of low-wage South Asian workers related to wage compensation, political asylum, and domestic violence. Court files include client intake files, court transcripts, attorney correspondence, court petitions, affidavits of support, and other documents describing the client's personal backgrounds. Many of these documents are in Hindi and Bengali. Administrative files include meeting minutes, agendas, by-laws, board evaluations of the organization's progress; financial records include grant contracts, interim progress reports, budget sheet narratives, fundraising plans, and tax records. The collection also includes a small amount of the organization's project files documenting global and local initiatives related to domestic violence, human trafficking, and human rights abuses in the domestic workers industry. Materials include reports, newspaper clippings from domestic and international publications, and ephemera.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright (or related rights to publicity and privacy) for materials in this collection, created by Andolan was not transferred to New York University. Permission to use materials must be secured from the copyright holder.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection has not been arranged by an archivist. The materials are arranged in the order in which they were received from the donor.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Andolan (Organizing South Asian Workers) is a non-governmental, membership based group in New York City that organizes and advocates on behalf of South Asian immigrant workers, with particular focus on Bangladeshi, Pakistani, Indian, Nepalese, and Sri Lankan workers in the retail, food service, and domestic work industries, many of whom are women. Founded in 1998 by low-wage South Asians, Andolan's goal is to support and empower working-class communities to realize their rights and overcome obstacles such as language barriers, discrimination, immigration status, and gaps in social services for legal assistance and other types of support. Andolan's major program areas include providing support to workers, promoting legal advocacy, and community campaigning through meetings, educational workshops, referrals for medical assistance, counseling, and translation services. The group supports members navigating the legal process against abusive employers for wage violations, sexual harassment, assault, domestic violence, and imprisonment. Andolan works in coalition with other organizations on campaigns related to worker's rights and human rights, such as the Campaign to Increase the Minimum Wage and the Campaign Against Diplomatic Immunity of UN Employees.
